SpNote.note:
A note about notes ----------------
This is a note outlining good practice in note writing for heterodyne MSB. PLEASE replace this note with your own note or delete altogether BEFORE submitting the MSB.
Things to include in your notes -------------------------------
* Calibration details
1) Overall observing strategy for your science program. A paragraph conveying the general ideas behind your science program is useful for the observer (who may not be an expert in your field) and the TSS. (Check "show to the Observer").
2) Details of calibration observations. Spell out any specific calibrations you require in the note which is selected as "show-to-observer". Example instructions might include:
"Short sample on a nearby spectral line standard with a good CO(3-2) line e.g. OMC1".
and/or
"Short sample on a point-like planet (e.g. Uranus), with same backend set up as science target."
In short, you'll at least want something to check back-end setup and receiver performance (e.g. a spectral line standard). Optional is an efficiency measurement on a planet to check the convertion of the measured antenna temperature to an astrophysical brightness temperature. However, isolated efficiency observations scatter considerably and using a suitable average of archived values may be preferential.
3) If you want more specific standard or calibration measurement you should make a separate MSBs with these measurements or include them as extra observation in your MSBs. Calibration observations should be flagged as 'calibration' on their title page to prevent unnecessary repeats.
SpNote.title: Please read

SpNote.note:
Calibrations: ----------
The JCMT observing software needs further development to enable a more flexible inclusion of calibration observations: presently there is no easy way to insert calibration observation MSBs. Without any specific instructions in the science program the operators will insert calibrations by observing one of the 'standard' lines in a calibration source. There are several options for the calibration: ==> See the 'Calibration Instructions' in the Optional Calibration Template in the ACSIS OT library for additional instructions regarding options 2 and 3.
PIs are strongly advised to, at a minimum, add instructions and wishes regarding calibrations in this 'Calibration Note' to the TSS and observers.
Examples:
1) No specific calibration MSB is provided. Calibrations can be carried out on a suitable calibration source selected by the TSS and at a 'standard' frequency, possibly different from MSB tuning or redshift.
2) A set of separate calibration MSBs, named ...., is available for use with this MSB. Please select one suitable for the time of observation, the MSBs span the range of RAs in the science program.
3) Calibration observations are embedded as an (optional) part of this MSB.
Please make sure to add additional wishes and requests to the note! Issue to consider may be:
- How important is a precise calibration? For many projects it is sufficient to ensure that the telescope and receiver are within spec.
- Can the calibration be done at a 'standard' frequency, possibly different from MSB tuning or redshift? Or should the calibration be done with the "Het setup" of the science observation and, if not close to a standard frequency, should a line-rich source be selected that will allow for the relative calibration of observations from night-to-night?
- Can the calibration be done using a different bandwidth than the science observation? Is an increase in bandwidth allowed to catch a nearby standard line? Increasing the bandwidth should not affect the calibration, except that the peak of very narrow lines will drop because of the lower resolution.
- Is it important to observe a planet? Can this be done at one of the standard frequencies or should the "Het setup" from the science MSB be used? Efficiencies derived from isolated observations of the continuum level of planets typically are not very accurate.
SpNote.title: Calibration

SpNote.note:
Calibrations: ----------
The JCMT observing software needs further development to enable a more flexible inclusion of calibration observations: presently there is no easy way to insert calibration observation MSBs. Without any specific instructions in the science program the operators will insert calibrations by observing one of the 'standard' lines in a calibration source. There are several options for the calibration: ==> See the 'Calibration Instructions' in the Optional Calibration Template in the ACSIS OT library for additional instructions regarding options 2 and 3.
PIs are strongly advised to, at a minimum, add instructions and wishes regarding calibrations in this 'Calibration Note' to the TSS and observers.
Examples:
1) No specific calibration MSB is provided. Calibrations can be carried out on a suitable calibration source selected by the TSS and at a 'standard' frequency, possibly different from MSB tuning or redshift.
2) A set of separate calibration MSBs, named ...., is available for use with this MSB. Please select one suitable for the time of observation, the MSBs span the range of RAs in the science program.
3) Calibration observations are embedded as an (optional) part of this MSB.
Please make sure to add additional wishes and requests to the note! Issue to consider may be:
- How important is a precise calibration? For many projects it is sufficient to ensure that the telescope and receiver are within spec.
- Can the calibration be done at a 'standard' frequency, possibly different from MSB tuning or redshift? Or should the calibration be done with the "Het setup" of the science observation and, if not close to a standard frequency, should a line-rich source be selected that will allow for the relative calibration of observations from night-to-night?
- Can the calibration be done using a different bandwidth than the science observation? Is an increase in bandwidth allowed to catch a nearby standard line? Increasing the bandwidth should not affect the calibration, except that the peak of very narrow lines will drop because of the lower resolution.
- Is it important to observe a planet? Can this be done at one of the standard frequencies or should the "Het setup" from the science MSB be used? Efficiencies derived from isolated observations of the continuum level of planets typically are not very accurate.

- Is it important to observe a planet? Can this be done at one of the standard frequencies or should the "Het setup" from the science MSB be used? Efficiencies derived from isolated observations of the continuum level of planets typically are not very accurate.
SpNote.title: Calibration (RxW)

SpNote.note:
A note about notes ----------------
This is a note outlining good practice in note writing for heterodyne MSB. PLEASE replace this note with your own note or delete altogether BEFORE submitting the MSB.
Things to include in your notes -------------------------------
* Calibration details
1) Overall observing strategy for your science program. A paragraph conveying the general ideas behind your science program is useful for the observer (who may not be an expert in your field) and the TSS. (Check "show to the Observer").
2) Details of calibration observations. Spell out any specific calibrations you require in the note which is selected as "show-to-observer". Example instructions might include:
"Short sample on a nearby spectral line standard with a good CO(3-2) line e.g. OMC1".
and/or
"Short sample on a point-like planet (e.g. Uranus), with same backend set up as science target."
In short, you'll at least want something to check back-end setup and receiver performance (e.g. a spectral line standard). Optional is an efficiency measurement on a planet to check the convertion of the measured antenna temperature to an astrophysical brightness temperature. However, isolated efficiency observations scatter considerably and using a suitable average of archived values may be preferential.
3) If you want more specific standard or calibration measurement you should make a separate MSBs with these measurements or include them as extra observation in your MSBs. Calibration observations should be flagged as 'calibration' on their title page to prevent unnecessary repeats.
SpNote.title: Please read

SpNote.note:
===================================== SPECIAL WARNING FOR RxW OBSERVATIONS:
RxW is a manually tuned receiver. Calibrations performed at a frequency different from the tuning used in the Science MSB may result in a significant increase of the overhead. =====================================
Calibrations: ----------
The JCMT observing software needs further development to enable a more flexible inclusion of calibration observations: presently there is no easy way to insert calibration observation MSBs. Without any specific instructions in the science program the operators will insert calibrations by observing one of the 'standard' lines in a calibration source. There are several options for the calibration: ==> See the 'Calibration Instructions' in the Optional Calibration Template in the ACSIS OT library for additional instructions regarding options 2 and 3.
PIs are strongly advised to, at a minimum, add instructions and wishes regarding calibrations in this 'Calibration Note' to the TSS and observers.
Examples:
1) No specific calibration MSB is provided. Calibrations can be carried out on a suitable calibration source selected by the TSS and at a 'standard' frequency, possibly different from MSB tuning or redshift.
2) A set of separate calibration MSBs, named ...., is available for use with this MSB. Please select one suitable for the time of observation, the MSBs span the range of RAs in the science program.
3) Calibration observations are embedded as an (optional) part of this MSB.
Please make sure to add additional wishes and requests to the note! Issue to consider may be:
- How important is a precise calibration? For many projects it is sufficient to ensure that the telescope and receiver are within spec.
- Can the calibration be done at a 'standard' frequency, possibly different from MSB tuning or redshift? Or should the calibration be done with the "Het setup" of the science observation and, if not close to a standard frequency, should a line-rich source be selected that will allow for the relative calibration of observations from night-to-night?
- Can the calibration be done using a different bandwidth than the science observation? Is an increase in bandwidth allowed to catch a nearby standard line? Increasing the bandwidth should not affect the calibration, except that the peak of very narrow lines will drop because of the lower resolution.
- Is it important to observe a planet? Can this be done at one of the standard frequencies or should the "Het setup" from the science MSB be used? Efficiencies derived from isolated observations of the continuum level of planets typically are not very accurate.

SpNote.title: Calibration (RxW)

SpNote.note: Pointing observation. Will normally be inserted as needed by TSS.
X, Y, or Z focus observation. Will normally be inserted when needed by TSS.

Calibration Template Instructions ----------------------------
PIs are strongly advised to, at a minimum, add instructions and wishes regarding calibrations in the 'Calibration Note' to the TSS and observers. A sample note has been included with the library templates. For information on standard sources, lines, and observational setup, see:
http://www.jach.hawaii.edu/JCMT/spectral_line/Standards/standards.html
Please be aware that the submm positions for calibrators as used at the JCMT may differ substantially from the the ones in archives such as SIMBAD.
There are several options for calibrations and ways to customize them:
1) No special calibration MSBs are provided in the Science Program: the calibrations will be carried out on a suitable calibration source selected by the TSS at a 'standard' frequency, possibly different from MSB tuning or redshift. For many applications, this is the most appropriate option.
2) A number of separate calibration MSBs on suitable targets are added to the science program, clearly identified as calibrations in their title. Typically the set of calibration MSBs should cover the RA-range of the science observations to ensure that at least one calibration MSB is available at any time. PIs can customize the "Het setup" but need to take care to pick an appropriate switching-scheme for each calibrator chosen. The TSS will insert the calibration MSBs into the observing queue as needed and per instruction in the science program.
3) Calibration observations are part of the science MSBs
Ad 2. Adding separate Calibration MSBs: ----------------------------------
The ACSIS library has a set of special template MSBs for a position-switch, beam-switch, or raster calibration. The MSBs start with a series of (optional) pointing and focus observations. The calibration itself is a regular observation that has been marked as a calibration. Configure the "Het setup" and "Target Component" to customize the calibration for your project. Typically choose either a position-switch, beam-switch, or raster calibration, depending on the selected calibration target (many of which require a position-switch). Observational details for the calibrators can be found at this location: http://www.jach.hawaii.edu/JCMT/spectral_line/Standards/standards.html The calibration MSBs should be added to the science program with a high priority (low number) and high repeat counter to ensure that they will come up prominently and repeatedly in the JCMT Query Tool.
Ad 3. Embedding Calibration observations as part of the science MSBs: -----------------------------------------------------------
Embed the calibration observation of a specific standard source and line in your science MSB by copying and pasting the desired components from the calibration template described above under Ad. 2 (please read those instructions). The MSB should look like:
------------------------- MSB ... Het setup Science Target Calibration Observation (marked as Calibration) Science Observation -------------------------
Please be aware of "inheritance": in the example above you will need to add another "Target Component" inside Calibration Observations with the coordinates and offsets of the calibrator! Likewise, if the calibration needs to be done at a different frequency, another "Het setup" needs to be added inside the Calibration Observation. This will result in the appropriate retune between the calibrator and the science target. This should NOT be done for the manually tuned RxW. WARNING: If you include a calibration observation in this manner, both your target and calibration source must be observable before the MSB can be scheduled, which can severely restrict the night-time available to the project in case of an unfortunate combination of calibration and science targets.
